awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Catalan Function and Schubert Calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
Combinatorics is an area of mathematics concerned with analyzing, organizing, and optimizing over discrete data.  It is a fundamental tool in many scientific areas such as genomics, computer science, statistics, and physics.  This project will develop combinatorial methods for attacking problems in algebra, geometry, and symmetric function theory, an area with applications to probability and statistical mechanics. A mutually beneficial component is the further development of the SAGE open-source mathematics software, a crucial tool for this investigation.

This project spans combinatorial problems in representation theory, algebraic geometry, and physics.  The inspiration comes from constructions such as tableaux and Bruhat posets which lie at the heart of classical mathematics such as Schubert calculus and the representation theory of the complex linear group.  Fundamental objects in our investigations are the Schur functions and generalizations known as k-Schur functions, which are closely tied to (affine) Schubert calculus.  This project will capitalize on PIs' recent work connecting k-Schur functions with certain Catalan symmetric functions to solve problems involving Macdonald polynomials, parabolic Hall-Littlewood polynomials, Gromov-Witten invariants, and the co(homology) and K-theory of affine Grassmannians.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
This program is in the area of algebraic combinatorics, a branch of mathematics integrating combinatorial and algebraic methods.  The basic idea is to hone in on tangible and computational aspects of a problem, identify or establish a combinatorial scaffolding around these elements, and subsequently develop the theory.  The beauty of an algebraic combinatorial approach is that it can be applied to problems in a wide spectrum of fields in math, computer science, and physics.  As such, the impact across disciplines is quite high.  Further, because the techniques span from computational to the abstract, the research appeals to diverse mathematical talent resulting in a significant human impact factor as well.

By bringing together affine Schubert calculus and Macdonald theory, the program led to the solution of that longest open problem in the field of diagonal harmonics as well as a number of other decades old problems in algebraic combinatorics. A key underlying idea is to realize objects of interest as various subclasses of a family of polynomials called Catalan functions.  The vastness of this family gives access to inductive techniques that are not available when restricting to the subclasses, but provide a powerful tool for their study.  This led to the resolution of a number of open problems, but more importantly opened the door on the notion of ''Catalanimals," symmetric rational functions which give a framework for studying Macdonald polynomials and the elliptic Hall algebra.


Last Modified: 11/10/2023
Modified by: Jennifer L Morse
